body: Depends on the chosen architecture, batchsize, image size. Seems reasonable. From software point of view, tensorflow device is created, memory gets allocated and it does run on the GPU so everyhing looks fine.
Good to know that it's actually working. Thanks for the confirmation!

Short explanation for the future viewers of this issue. GPU usage is shown based on some internal calculations that might differ between different die architectures, drivers, workloads etc. A well optimized workload might show low GPU usage as in, at given time the resources (CUDA cores for instance) are utilized in 2-3% but when you look at the memory usage, with DLC (more specifically it's tensorflow that allocates it) the memory will be almost entirely allocated (doesn't have to be used entirely but it's reserved for this workload anyway). So in reality, though a lot of memory is being used, calculations performed on data located in this memory are very efficient (and might be bottlenecked by the memory bus - how much data can be transferred from memory to the GPU to be processed) and don't need to use more than the 2-3% of your cores. 

To sum up, what you should look at if you're not sure if your training/inference is being done on the GPU look at the GPU memory usage and if the Tensorflow device was created using GPU_device (printed when running e.g. training)
I think this would be another good page for the cookbook (“How to tell if deeplabcut is fully using your GPU”) since it has come up repeatedly.

> I think this would be another good page for the cookbook (“How to tell if deeplabcut is fully using your GPU”) since it has come up repeatedly.

Since I'll be doing a DLC workshop for some people in 2-3 weeks I might try to write all of this down for the cookbook as part of workshop preparations. If you (or anybody else) think there is some other thing that could be useful let me know, I might have some free time to do this after I finish current experiment.

issue.title: Training doesn't reach first iteration -- due to CUDA/TF version mismatch causes by pinned numpy

repository.name: DeepLabCut
repository.description: Official implementation of DeepLabCut: Markerless pose estimation of user-defined features with deep learning for all animals incl. humans

license.name: GNU Lesser General Public License v3.0

issue.body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues

### Bug description

Training starts and appears to recognize GPU but never reaches first iteration and GPU levels on task manager stay around 0-2%. It also doesn't seem to engage the CPU as leaving it 'training' overnight still doesn't have any iterations so it's not just working slow. Only encountered this issue when I updated my deeplabcut setup from the original DLC-GPU to the new version (DLC 2.2.0.1)

### Operating System

Windows 10.0.18362
python 3.8
CUDA 11.0

### DeepLabCut version

dlc version= 2.2.0.1

### DeepLabCut mode

single animal

### Device type

GeForce RTX 2080 SUPER

### Steps To Reproduce

1. Go to Envs of anaconda navigator and open DEEPLABCUT with ipython
2. import deeplabcut (2021-08-31 10:59:50.660626: I tensorflow/stream_executor/platform/default/dso_loader.cc:44] Successfully opened dynamic library cudart64_101.dll)
3. Train network with previously labeled data from older DLC [deeplabcut.train_network('config path\\config.yaml', shuffle=1,trainingsetindex=0,gputouse=0,max_snapshots_to_keep=5, displayiters=1000,saveiters=20000, maxiters=500000)]

### Relevant log output

body: @backyardbiomech any interest in making your excellent suggestion of a how to tell your GPU is used recipe :) ?
Happy to, but I’m going on vacation for a week today, so it will have to wait.
